awd_titl_txt: An Atom-Probe Tomography and Lattice Kinetic Monte Carlo Study of Phase Separation in Ni-Al-Based Alloys from the Atomic Scale Up to Link with Continuum Theories
awd_abstract_narration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY: The kinetic pathways in the early stages of phase separation of a concentrated multicomponent supersaturated solid-solution are critical to the development of the final microstructure, which is of significant technological importance for controlling the physical and mechanical properties of a material at the macroscopic scale. On the theoretical side, kinetic pathways are described in terms of nucleation, growth and coarsening, whose theory implies diffusion in the matrix, transfer of atoms across a matrix/precipitate interface together with the assumption of local equilibrium. The most recent achievements of high-yield atom-probe tomography (APT) and fast lattice kinetic Monte Carlo (LKMC) simulations make it possible to describe phase separation at the atomic scale. The necessary parameters for the thermodynamics and kinetics are deduced from first-principles calculations and experimental fits for the LKMC parameters. In the case of coherent precipitation, phase separation is simply the footprint left by the myriad of vacancy jumps in the inhomogeneous distribution of atomic species. Because the same vacancy jumps are at work in the equilibrium solid-solution, a link is established between features of kinetic pathways and diffusion in a solid-solution. Our APT experimental results demonstrate directly that correlation effects (flux-couplings) in solid-state diffusion control the early stage kinetic pathway for coherent-phase separation. Such effects are neglected by all extant variants of nucleation theory, which all rely on a simplified form of the diffusion matrix. We have developed a transformative approach that employs state-of-the-art APT coupled with LKMC simulations and diffusion theory for phase separation, which studies the kinetic pathways experimentally and models it via simulations and diffusion theory. And we have demonstrated the uniqueness of this approach for concentrated Ni-Al-Cr alloys. The combined use of APT and LKMC in model Ni-base superalloys provides a unique data-base (experimental and LKMC results) for developing a new theory of nucleation in binary (Ni-Al) and concentrated multi-component alloys (Ni-Al-Cr and Ni-Al-Mo). Classical nucleation theory assumes that the atomic fluxes are such that the decomposition path follows the steepest slope of the configurational free energy surface, whereas kinetic coupling of the fluxes is one reason why this isn't generally correct: also the disparate diffusivities involved is another reason. Our approach will take into account the coupled-flux effects that lead to nucleation of a second phase. In this new approach the interfacial width should be affected by the diffusion mechanism (unlike in the Cahn-Hilliard formalism). Additionally, we propose to implement a parallel LKMC simulation code for multi-component systems based on perfect time synchronicity, which is based on a code developed by Martinez et al. at LANL that will accelerate the LKMC simulations. The proposed research will lead to a completely different way of viewing kinetic pathways for phase separation of a solid-solution, and hence, nucleation, growth and coarsening.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY: Our unique approach to phase separation makes extensive use of a local-electrode atom-probe (LEAP) tomograph in the Northwestern University Center for Atom-Probe Tomography (NUCAPT). NUCAPT is unique university facility in the US, which has had and will have a significant impact on the research efforts of undergraduate work-study, senior thesis, research experiences for undergraduates (REU), M.S., Ph.D. and postdoctoral students: during the last four years many underrepresented groups of students have used NUCAPT. In the Department of Materials Science and Engineering at Northwestern six professors and their students make extensive use of NUCAPT. Additionally, NUCAPT has users from other US universities, and both national and industrial laboratories. Research results based on atom-probe tomography are published in the archival literature and our web site, http://nucapt.northwestern.edu , has a library from which reprints can downloaded as PDF files. Through NUCAPT we have educated a large number of people in the application of atom-probe tomography to a wide range of materials science and engineering problems, which is important for characterizing materials at the subnanoscale scale. Additionally, we are interacting with a materials scientist in France on the subject matter of this research and are supplying service to industrial companies in the US and abroad. There is no one else in the US doing this to the extent that we are accomplishing this objective.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Commercial Ni-based superalloys are used for single-crystal turbine blades in aircraft engines (military and commercial) and land-based natural-gas fired turbine engines because of their high strength, creep, oxidation and corrosion resistance, and toughness at elevated temperatures. The key nanostructural feature of Ni-based superalloys is a high volume fraction (~70-80 %) of coherent, ordered-Ni3Al precipitates (γ’-phase) inside a disordered Ni-rich f.c.c. matrix (γ-phase). The outstanding high-temperature strength results from the nucleation, growth, and coarsening of the γ’(L12)-precipitate phase, though continued coarsening during usage at elevated temperatures. We observed the temporal evolution of γ’-precipitate for life-time from nucleation to final coarsening stage in three dimensional with atomic scale utilizing atom probe tomography (APT) and lattice-kinetic Monte Carlo (LKMC) simulations. APT is a unique analytical instrument, which utilizes the phenomenon of evaporation employing voltage pulse and/or pulsed UV (wavelength = 355 nm) laser to dissect a specimen, whereby individual atoms are desorbed as single and molecular ions on the surface of a nanoscale hemispherical nanotip. And the LKMC1 simulations takes into account the physics of the atomic jump frequency via a mono-vacancy for understanding physical mechanism is thermally-activated diffusion via a mono-vacancy mechanism. 

  The present research concentrates on comparing the temporal evolution and kinetic pathways for phase separation in a binary Ni-Al, and ternary Ni-Al-Cr and Ni-Al-Mo alloys, which are the basis of modern Ni based superalloys. To study the kinetics of phase separation in any alloy requires measuring the following basic physical quantities as a function of aging time (t): (a) Mean precipitate radius; (b) Number density; (c) Volume fraction; (d) Supersaturations of all elements for nucleation and coarsening; (e) Average concentrations; (f) Precipitate size distributions; (g) Concentration profiles of all elements between the matrix- and precipitate-phases; (h) Fraction of precipitates interconnected by necks; (i) Interfacial width between the precipitates and matrix phases; (j) inter-precipitate distance distributions; and (k) the morphology of the precipitates. All the experimental results are compared to computer based LKMC simulations and diffusion theory. To analyze phase separation, a diffusion theory of nucleation in concentrated multi-component alloys is developed that takes full advantage of a normal mode analysis to reformulate the classic nucleation theory of coherent phase separation that incorporates the complete details of solid-state diffusion. There are semi-quantitative agreement between simulations and experiment and we conclude that our experimental results permit us to use the experimentally obtained coarsening rate constants to calculate the inter-diffusion coefficient of Ni and Al in our in a binary Ni-Al, and to modern Ni based super-alloy. The atomic scale experiment in APT and simulation in LKMC in Ni based superalloy permit us valuable physical insights into the origin of temporal evolution and kinetic pathways for phase separation, which will help with a further rational alloying design and prediction of life time of these Ni based alloy to achieve higher strength and creep resistance.

 The experimental approach we are utilizing had been emulated by other groups around the world. The techniques we have developed for atom-probe tomography are also relevant for other filed of material science studying: thin-film reactions; interfacial segregation; chemical changes due to radiation damage; magnetic tunnel junctions; organic/inorganic interfaces, et cetera. Specifically, Prof. L. Lauhon (Northwestern University) studies silicon nanowires grown by the vapor-liquid-solid technique, Prof. D. Joester (Northwestern University) studies organic/inorganic interfaces, Prof. H. D. Espinosa (Northwestern University) studies GaN nanowires, Prof. Yip-Wah Chung studies ultrastrong steels with Professor Emeritus Morris E. Fine (Northwestern University). Prof. Seidman studies thermoelectric materials in collaboration with Prof. M. Kanatzidis (Chemistry Department, Northwestern University). We also collaborate with companies by performing their research for First Solar, Questek, A. O. Smith, and Apple.

 PDF files of all articles published by our research group are available on the group'swebsite, http://nucapt.northwestern.edu. NUCAPT Lab tours were offered for prospective graduate students of the MSE department in March 2016. NUCAPT’s VG FIM100 atom-probe field-ion (APFIM) microscope has been exhibited at Chicago's Museum of Science and Industry in the “Materials Science” exhibition that opened in March 2015. This exhibition has now been moved to publicly accessible space in Terminals 1 and 3 at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport and since late May 2016 the historic VG FIM100 APFIM instrument is on display in the airport concourse between gates B11 and B12 in Terminal 1.NUCAPT will upgrade the LEAP to 5000 XS. which combines new flight path technology with enhanced detector performance to offer improved field of view whilst achieving unprecedented detection efficiency about 80%, the highest of any such analytical technique. All the experimental data and  and  post-processed results are automatically stored and backed up in a new NUCAPT data server, which includes redundant hardware mechanisms to ensure continuity of the operation of NUCAPT.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 08/30/2017
Modified by: David N Seidman

The key nanostructural feature of Ni-based superalloys is a high volume fraction (~70-80 %) of coherent, ordered-Ni3Al precipitates (γ?-phase) inside a disordered Ni-rich f.c.c. matrix (γ-phase). The outstanding high-temperature strength results from the nucleation, growth, and coarsening of the γ?(L12)-precipitate phase, though continued coarsening during usage at elevated temperatures. We observed the temporal evolution of γ?-precipitate for life-time from nucleation to final coarsening stage in three dimensional with atomic scale utilizing atom probe tomography (APT) and lattice-kinetic Monte Carlo (LKMC) simulations.
